Speaker: frances
Dialogue: It usually worked. God became a superfather that couldn't spank me. But if I wanted a thing badly enough, He arranged it.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: But if God loved all of His children equally, why did He bother about my red hat and let other people lose their fathers and mothers for always?

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: Bye, baby.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: See you next weekend, Dad.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I began to see that He didn't have much to do about hats or people dying or anything. They happened whether He wanted them to or not, and He stayed in Heaven and pretended not to notice.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I wondered a little why God was such a useless thing. It seemed a waste of time to have Him. After that He became less and less, until He was... nothingness.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I felt rather proud that I had found the truth myself, without help from anyone. It puzzled me that other people hadn't found out, too. God was gone. We had reached past Him. Why couldn't they see it? It still puzzles me.

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: You're going straight to hell, Frances Farmer!

Speaker: kaminski
Dialogue: And do you think it's radical for a man to have a job and feed a family?

Speaker: kaminski
Dialogue: Is it radical for you to have a hand in shaping your future, and the future of your children?

Speaker: kaminski
Dialogue: Is it radical for the wealth of this country to be turned back to the people who built the country?

Speaker: kaminski
Dialogue: Good! Because, Brothers, that's you!

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: Seattle is in the news again as a high school junior wins a national competition and a hundred dollar prize with an essay denying God.

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: This prompts civic officials to charge that left-wing politicians are encouraging atheism in the city's schools. Miss Frances Farmer was unavailable for comment, but her mother Lillian --

Speaker: announcer
Dialogue: Farmer, a well-known local dietician, stepped to her daughter's defense.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: Frances has not turned her back on the Lord, they're just having a momentary difference of opinion. What child hasn't questioned the Lord's mysteries in order to better understand them? To paraphrase Mr. Voltaire, I may not agree with what she says, but I'll defend to the death her right to say it. Freedom of speech, unlike in the dark countries to the east, still lives in America! And in my home.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Hi Emma.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Bye Emma.

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: Hey!

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: C'mere. I wanna talk to you.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Momma told ya not to speak to strangers, huh?  Hey!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Don't touch me.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: I'm not gonna hurt you. I just wanna talk.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Okay then...

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Well... you're causin' trouble, you know that?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I'm causing trouble?! You're a pain in the butt! You newshounds've been after me and my folks ever since I won that dumb contest. I'm just sixteen, you know? Who the hell cares what I think?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Not me. But other people seem to.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Yeah. Well if you didn't put it in the papers -- nobody'd even know about it.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Now wait a minute, sweetie. Do I look like a newshound to you?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: No... Actually, you look more like a cop.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: That's rich. Hey, if I was a cop, I'd be packing, right?  You see a gun? Go on, search me. Pat me down.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I'll... take your word for it. So who are you, then?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Harry York. I work for Martoni Kaminski, he's running for Congress here.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Oh yeah! I saw you in the newsreel!

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Yeah, well --

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: You know, my Dad's done some work for Kaminski...

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Now you're catchin' on. Don't wanna get your Daddy in hot water, do you?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Whattaya mean?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Well... see the papers've got us pegged as pinkos, then you come along, the friendly neighborhood atheist --

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: But I'm not. The newspapers're --

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Right again. You're no more an atheist than my man's a Red, but what they're doin', see, they're addin' up their version of your ideas with their version of ours. Could look bad for your Daddy.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Yeah. Could look bad for you and Kaminski too, I guess.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Sure don't talk like you're sixteen.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Well aren't you the smoothie. Now you're going to ask for my number, I suppose.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: I suppose not. Gotta ask you this, though: for all our sakes, you better keep your trap shut.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Well... I'll give it a try, Mr. York.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Harry.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Harry.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Bye.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Sure don't walk like sixteen, neither.

Speaker: hillier
Dialogue: These are perilous times. With the economic collapse comes hopelessness and desperation; and people turn to dangerous ideas --

Speaker: woman's voice
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: hillier
Dialogue: Those of us who represent law and order must be vigilant. Who's behind this, her mother?

Speaker: styles
Dialogue: Impossible. As her attorney, I've known her for years.

Speaker: hillier
Dialogue: What about the father, he's a little pink. Maybe he wants to show our schools in a bad light, shift some support to Kaminski and those jackals.

Speaker: styles
Dialogue: He's no influence; he doesn't even live at home. No, I think Frances wrote that essay with no mischief intended. It was her teacher who entered it in the competition.

Speaker: hillier
Dialogue: Well, the publicity must stop. It's no good for Seattle and no good for the country.  Keep an eye on this, will you, Alma?

Speaker: styles
Dialogue: Of course, your honor.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: It always amazes me, Lil, how you can whip up a hot, hearty meal out of thin air.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: I can thank you for that. It was a hard-earned talent.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: Bread?

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: When's the last time you saw a hundred dollars, Ernest Farmer?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Mama...

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: I'm not hungry. You two just enjoy yourselves. After all, this is a celebration.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: I'm... I'm really proud of you, Frances.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Thanks, Dad.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: An essay contest... a national contest. That's pretty impressive.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I didn't have much to do with it.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: You wrote it, didn't you?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Yeah, I suppose... Dad, who's Harry York?

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: Well, Harry York is a guy who... well, he does a lot of things. Why do you ask?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: He talked to me today. Told me to keep my mouth shut or I'd get everybody in trouble.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: Yeah... well... it's possible. Harry York and I both work for Mr. Kaminski right now, and... well... There are lots of folks in this country who never got a square break. That's the way of things, but Mr. Kaminski wants to change it, and when it comes to new ideas, the people in power get nervous.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Is Kaminski a Communist?

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: No, no, no. All he wants to do is see the common man get a little representation.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: He's a socialist, then?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: And I can't understand how it can hurt to be honest, but the more I tried to explain --

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: Don't listen to him, little sister. When you're proud of what you are, you don't refuse the label, understand?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Yes, Ma.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: And you... should be proud. You won that contest and made a name for yourself.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: You're poisoning that child's mind.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: I have a right to talk to her. She's my daughter, and she's beginning to understand why I've sacrificed so much in order to achieve...

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: You've sacrificed?! If you'd practice law for decent folk instead of Communists and indigents --

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: They need help, Lil. They pay me back in other ways.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: How? What do they do for you, Kaminski and his friends? They're all anarchists! Traitors!

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: No, Lil. It's just you can't understand their brand of patriotism.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: That's right. I can't understand a man who puts strangers over his family, a man who gives up a good career to become a shiftless inkhorn failure.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: I'm going back to the hotel.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: Good.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: See you next weekend?

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: As usual. Everything as usual, Mr. Farmer. Just give me my due.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: Lillian... I'm more than willing to meet you halfway.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: Don't make me sick. I'd sooner drown myself in Puget Sound.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: That's a thought, Lil. That sure is a thought.

Speaker: neighbor's voice
Dialogue: Are you all right, dear?

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: I'm fine, perfectly fine.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Dad, please, don't leave early. Just because of Mama --

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: Francie, you'll learn that sometimes it's best to stay low and just walk away.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: What can we do, we must live! We shall live, Uncle Vanya...

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: And then we shall rest, we shall rest. We shall hear the angels, we shall see the whole sky all diamonds, we shall see how all earthly evil, all our sufferings, are drowned in the mercy that will fill the whole world. And our life will grow peaceful, tender, sweet as a caress...  We shall rest!

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Not bad, Farmer. Not half bad.

Speaker: drama teacher
Dialogue: Art is a constant struggle. Some of you have the will but not the ability. For others, the opposite. I don't wish to be harsh, but only one of you on stage tonight combined the two...

Speaker: drama teacher
Dialogue: On cue.

Speaker: drama teacher
Dialogue: This is the answer: a subscription drive to "Voice of Action!" First prize is a trip to Moscow! You could visit the art theatre, maybe even meet Stanislavski!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: But I'll never win that.

Speaker: drama teacher
Dialogue: Yes, yes, it's all arranged. Everyone's collecting subscriptions in your name. And the best part is: the trip returns you to New York.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Really?

Speaker: drama teacher
Dialogue: New York, Frances! Broadway! This is your chance! You belong on the stage!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Hi, Harry. Did you see the play?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: You think I'd miss it?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Well? What'd you think?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: I just wanted to see how you looked.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: How'd I look?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Enh.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Don't be a rat, Harry.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: You looked okay.  Joint's pretty dead. How 'bout I take you home?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Honest. When you were up there, you were really... there, know what I mean? Everyone else looked stupid.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I don't know... I did... feel different... Alive.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Yeah, it's a gift. You gotta do something with it.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Yeah, but if I win this trip, Mama'll kill me. She hates Russians. I do want to go, though... to New York, especially... but I wanted to do it...

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Quietly.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: You're not the quiet type, Frances.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: You know, my old man was an inventor. Spent his whole life down in the basement trying to design transcontinental underground railroads, stuff like that. Well, I was supposed to be his partner. When I told him the smell of his workshop made me sick, I thought he was going to die right there.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: What happened to him?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: He retired to Florida... made a killing in vending machines.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: I kick myself sometimes, but the thing is, I would have been miserable living his life.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: ...So you think I should go.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Sure. Try this acting thing. You can make good money at it.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I don't know, Harry. I... I want so many...

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: You don't know what you want.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Not in the long run, anyway.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Frances...

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Well... don't you think it's up to me to...

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Come on, Harry. This is America, land of the free.  For starters.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: Communists?! No daughter of mine is going to Communist Russia!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: You act like I'm a bomb-thrower, Mama. It's just a trip.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: But they're using you!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Oh Ma, they're not using me. It's just a chance to travel, see things. Besides, it's the only way I can get to New York.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: I'll pay your way to New York. I'll work, I'll slave. I'll sell my vegetables to the truck farmers, or --

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Oh, Mama, don't you understand?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I have to do this on my own. You see, I've learned your lesson very well. To do what I think is right and everyone else be damned.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: I never taught you that!

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: Little sister, if you don't wise up soon, it's going to be out of my hands!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: It isn't in your hands, Mama. It's my life.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: Yes, but important people are concerned about this. Judge Hillier spoke to Alma Styles --

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I don't care.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: ...You will.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: What do I do, Dad?

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: You really want to go?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: And you think it's worth all this?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: If I didn't, I wouldn't put you through it.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: ...Then go.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: American integrity, that's what's at stake here. They're sending my daughter to the heartland of darkness. . .the dark forces that would overthrow our country. Your country. My country.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I'm not a Communist.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I said all countries are of cultural interest. Besides, Russia has the greatest theatre company in the world.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Not much. Ask me about Stanislavski.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: Help me save my daughter! Save the children of America.

Speaker: crowd
Dialogue: Repent! Repent!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I love you, Mama.  I love you, Dad.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: Be careful, Francie.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: Frances, I'm warning you. I'm gonna throw myself beneath the wheels. I'll do it, Frances. Frances!

Speaker: first reporter
Dialogue: What do you say now, Mrs. Farmer?

Speaker: publicist
Dialogue: Hobbies?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Oh, I swim some... play the piano badly... and I read like a fiend: I like history.

Speaker: publicist
Dialogue: No, no, people don't want that. Now listen: you spend lots of time at the beach. You're crazy about dancing. And you're the kind of girl who's just a little in love with love. Get it? Now try again? Hobbies?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Look, I...

Speaker: publicist
Dialogue: Beach... dancing... in love with love.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: That's me.

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Good morning, Mr. Bebe!

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: Who's this?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Frances Farmer, contract player, six- month option.

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: Okay. Good tits. Can't we show them off a little more?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: I guess so, sir.

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: Very fine bone structure.

Speaker: publicist
Dialogue: 'The most interesting thing about Frances Farmer is that her road to Hollywood was 12,000 miles long. After winning a beauty contest, the first prize of which was a trip to Europe...' She made some deal with the Commies and went to Moscow, but I'm not going to say that, am I?

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: Heavens no. Go on.

Speaker: publicist
Dialogue: Um... 'Miss Farmer returned to New York City and had a brief fling with the Broadway stage before coming west to seek stardom.'

Speaker: claire
Dialogue: 'Brief fling?'

Speaker: publicist
Dialogue: Well, actually she couldn't get hired, but lucky for her, some guy in our New York office saw her. She says soon as she gets a stake, she's going back.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Did you get the check?... Oh my God, it opened?!, what'd you think?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Well, I hope I get bigger parts, they don't come much smaller.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: No, I'm fine. I just have water in my mouth.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: No, Mama, I'm not changing my name. They can't actually make you, you know? Most people don't realize that.  Oh Dick...

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: No, no, nothing's going on.  I love you too, Mama. Give my love to Dad. Bye!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Okay, handsome. You win.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Kurt!

Speaker: fire chief
Dialogue: Oh, Angela! Go with these trappers! They'll lead you safely down the mountain...

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: But, Kurt, I...

Speaker: fire chief
Dialogue: No, No arguments. Be my good girl and go. There's a forest, a burning forest, and you know what I have to do!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Oh, Kurt!

Speaker: fire chief
Dialogue: Oh Angela, my own... Angela!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I'm sorry...  I'm sorry, let's go back.

Speaker: laughing man
Dialogue: That's talent, Andy.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Harry! Harry-god-damn-York! A real person!

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: How ya doin', Farmer?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Me? Look at you! What're you doing in Hollywood?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Came to get a tan.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Not bad. But come on, Harry; what's the real reason?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Kaminski.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Yeah, I read about that. Terrible business, suicide.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Since when do you believe the papers? They killed him, kid.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: They killed him. They threw him out that window.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Oh no...

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Eight stories.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Jesus.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Yup. Poor bastard lay there on the sidewalk and he couldn't die. Too god damn much heart. He just didn't want to die.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: But... but why, Harry...? Why'd they do it?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: How d'ya like the camouflage?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: You jackass!  C'mon, let's get out of here.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Not bad. It was slow at first, but I'm doing bits now.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: I always told ya, Frances. You got real ability.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I know what ability you're interested in.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Hey, I'm a man, aren't I? Whattaya say we have dinner, then maybe head out to the beach, rub some of this tan off each other.  For old time's sake.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Harry... I met someone.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Yeah? What is he -- muscleman? Lifeguard?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Actor?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Good. Then it's temporary.  All actors are phonies.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Serious, huh?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Yeah.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Hey that's great, Farmer, just great.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: These creases... I look like I just came from the laundry! I'm supposed to be hiding out in boxcars, sleeping on floors.

Speaker: wardrobe mistress
Dialogue: This is the suit we fitted on you, Miss Farmer.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Oh, I know that. But it could look more realistic, don't you think?

Speaker: wardrobe mistress
Dialogue: It'll do. No one will notice.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I'll notice.

Speaker: wardrobe mistress
Dialogue: Oh, Mr. Bebe, good morning.

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: Come along with me, Fanny.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: That's Frances. I'm not the cookbook.

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: You see: We've got to change that name.

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: I like your looks. You have the classical bone structure of the very great beauties... Garbo, Dietrich --

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Thank you --

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: I intend to make a great deal of money off you.

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: Since we have you on a seven year contract, I'm planning long-range. I'm going to loan you out to Sam Goldwyn to make a picture called "Come and Get It."

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Really? That's a very good book. It'd make a terrific --

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: Never mind that. I'm concerned about you. Your attitude.

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: Society is falling apart, Miss Farmer, and people have to buckle down, do their jobs. You see, I view myself as the Henry Ford of motion picture industry, and I can't have the fellow who puts on the wheels arguing with the man who installs head-lights, now can I?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: But I'm concerned with everything, Mr. Bebe.

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: No, I'm concerned with everything.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: But I'm the one up there on the screen.

Speaker: bebe
Dialogue: That's right. You're an actress, Miss Farmer and your job is to act.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Not bad, Farmer.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: I guess it's no secret that I'm proud. Only twenty-one years old, and look at all she's done.  As for her looks, I flatter myself that she gets them from me.

Speaker: dick
Dialogue: Obviously.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: And not only has Frances come home a star; she's also brought me this big handsome lug of a son-in-law!

Speaker: reporter
Dialogue: Mr. Farmer, what was your reaction when Frances told you she had married...

Speaker: dick
Dialogue: Dwayne. Dwayne Steele.

Speaker: ernest
Dialogue: What...? Oh. Well, I was pleased, of course. Richard... uh, Dwayne, is a real gentleman.

Speaker: dick
Dialogue: Well, all I can say is: I feel like I've known these two for years!

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: This is like a fairy tale!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: What'd he say?

Speaker: studio executive
Dialogue: Let's go. We'll be late.

Speaker: lillian
Dialogue: There she is!

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: A little strange.

Speaker: women's voices
Dialogue: Isn't she gorgeous?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: It's okay.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Well, the truth is the city had nothing to do with it. I was lucky. And what wasn't luck was hard work.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Excuse me.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Don't I know you?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Sure. You shouted at me in the auditorium when I read my essay.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Oh bullshit.

Speaker: judge hillier
Dialogue: I beg your pardon?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Listen, I'm still the same girl that wrote that essay, the same girl who went to Russia, and you people aren't proud to meet me at all.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: ...It's one thing to marry the guy, but did you have to sleep with him?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Shit. I meant the other way around.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Well, the studio told me not to.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Is that why you did it?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Who ever thought they'd be right for once? Jesus, Harry... it's a zoo back there --

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: You're telling me.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Dick... and my mother! She acts like she's on Mars or something --

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Well, she's back to earth now. They're all pretty huffed up about your leaving. I think you better go back, kid.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Forget it.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: You know, the funny thing is: it's not a great movie. I mean it could've been, but they screwed it up, gave it a happy ending. And all my friends, I know they're going to smile and say they loved it.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: If they say they love it, they'll probably love it. Not everybody lies, you know?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: No, they don't, do they?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Frances, you're a movie star now. If you give them what they want, you can get anything.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: I don't have what they want, Harry.  Harry, will you tell me something? How can I keep making movies when people in the streets are starving?

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Some people starve, kid. Until we can do something about it, they might as well see a movie. Makes 'em feel better.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: But I don't want to be like that. I want to do something...

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: What're you gonna do, waste your talent? Why not use it to make something worthwhile. You can do that, you know?

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Yeah, if I don't make too big an ass of myself.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Tell you what. Let's ditch the limo. Let me drive you up to that red carpet in my beat up Chevy.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: The hell you will, Harry York.

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Come on, Cinderella, your pumpkin awaits.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: Bong... bong... bong...

Speaker: harry
Dialogue: Don't start, Farmer.

Speaker: frances
Dialogue: It's midnight, Harry. My glittering raiments are dissolving.

Speaker: harry
